metadata.title: Synergism and phase transfer effects in hydrogenations of model coal constituents using iron carbonyl as a catalyst

LYNCH, 14fAHMOUD BANAH. MARK McDOUGALL and HERBERT D. KAESZ Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of California. Los Angeles, C.4 90024 (U.S_A.) ' CLIFFORD R. PORT-'ER Peretanyl Technologies, Inc-, 11728 fghmay 93, Boulder, CO 80303 (US_A.) (Received April 20, 1982) The recent report of investigations into hydrogenation of model coal constituents using metal carbonyls as catalysts [Z] prompts us to communicate results of our studies in this area which are focussed on iron carbonyl catalyzed systems [2, 3, 4] . As recently described [5] , iron pentacarbdnyl is an economically viable agent for desulfurization and liquefaction of coal. It is thus of interest to elucidate its activity in the hydrogenation of organic substrates; this reaction is currently being investigated for a variety of metal carbonyls [1] , and was earlier studied by 1. (Gender and co-workers using cobalt carbonyl with hydrogen [6, 71. Experimental Reactions were performed in a glass liner fitted to a 0.3 1 copper-lined autoclave. Reaction temperature was reached in one hour. Products were isolated by CC14 extraction of the glass liner contents, followed by drying and evaporation. Characterization was achieved by IR, lH and E3C NMR and mass spectral methods. Sampling of the gas phase above the reaction mixture during venting shows both HZ and C0z (by gas chromatography), indicating that the water-gas shift reaction had taken place. This is true both with and (at 300 C) without added Fe(Ca)S. In the latter case, however, only acridine shows any significant hydrogenation; the other substrates are unaffected. The water-gas shift reaction during the blank runs could be caused by the interior surface of the autoclave which comes into contact with gaseous HZ0 and CO. 0304-5102/82/0000-0000/S02. 75 Elsevier .9equoia/Printed in The Netherlands 110 Results and Discussion Our studies are summarized in the three tables which follow. Initially, we examined the :reactions at 150 `C to optimize the iron carbonyl-catalyzed water-gas shift reaction [2, 3] (see Table Z). Nitrogen heterocycles are found most susceptible to hydrogenation under these conditions. Quinoline, 1, is 100% hydrogenated in the nitrogen-containing ring; isoquinoline. 3, is both hydrogenated and 1Al-formylatted to 4, similarly in 100% yield. Fn the phenanthrolines, hydrogenation of only one of the two nitrogen-containing rings is observed. The yield o0 is significantly reduced because it is present in the product mixture in the form of iron complexes; this is indicated by a brightly colored aqueous phase partially characterized by the 1H NMR of acetone-d6 extracts. Anthracene is relatively unreactive under these conditions. We have however found ways in which its hydrogenation clay be significantly increased, see below. Compounds which we found to be unaffected at 150 C are naphthalene, phenanthrene, dibenzyl, anisole, diphenyl ether and dibenzthiophene. In light of the 100% yields observed in the conversions of 3 and 5, these reactions were performed using catalytic amounts of iron carbonyl; the results are listed in Table 2. At 150 9C, 22 and 24 molar equivalents of each of these substrates, respectively, are hydrogenated. Reactions were next undertaken at 300 C to parallel coal. liquefactions which were observed in higher yield at the higher temperature [9] . Using catalytic amounts of Fe(CO)S, isoquinoline is again hydrogenated and N-formylated wit'i a total turnover number of 35 (Table 2). Dibenzthiophene, on the other hand, remains unreactive. Other studies at 300 rZ,' are suaruunarized in Table 3. The first entry shows that anthracene, when treated by itself,. is less converted (19%) than it pas at 150 CC. It occu-rred to us that some of tile constituents in coal might affect the catalytic properties of Fe(CO)S. We therefore carried out experiments in which the reduction of anthracene was investigated in the presence of the substances listed in the next three entries in Table 3. With these a greater degree of conversion of anthrecene to 12 is observed. The nitrogen heterocycles are thus beneficial to reductions catalyzed by iron pentacarbonyl while the same nitrogen heterocycles are themselves undergoing conversion to partially hydrogenated (and/or N-formylated) products. Notably, the nitrogen heterocycles 9 and 14 which may participate as chelating ligands on iron were more effective for hydrogenation of anthracene than 1. Finally we come to the last two entries in Table 3, showing the results of addition of a phase transfer catalyst, tetramethyiammonium chloride, zither by itself or together with a nitrogen heterocycle. These lead to dramatic increases in the conversion of the anthracene. Such results at 300 C contrast with the work of Alper and co-workers, who reported no benefit of a phase transfer agent in the reduction of aromatic nitro compounds by Fe(CO)S (or Fe,(CO)9) at room temperature [10].
